The Alarm Correlation Policy (ACP) enables the Network Operations Center (NOC) employees to correlate the alarms of certain pattern, and show a single alarm which can represent the root cause problem in a better way. This feature can also be customized to suppress the symptom alarms.
The Correlation policies are applicable to both network and service alarms.
For each set of alarms that match a correlation policy, any of the following actions may be applied automatically.
The system periodically scans all correlated alarms and automatically clears the alarm that no longer has related alarms, for robustness.

If there are more than one filter expressions, then the alarm(s) should match all the filter expression conditions before it is checked for the Grouping Expression.
For example: If we have 6 alarms, then all 6 alarms passes independently through each filter expression of correlation policy based on the expression criteria and grouping criteria.
Once the grouping is completed the event threshold gets validated against each filter expression.
If each filter expression group is satisfied and the threshold against each expression, then the alarm correlated gets raised.

If the alarm(s) satisfies all the conditions in the grouping expression, it will be checked for the occurrence time. If there are more than one alarm, the alarms that are raised within the duration mentioned in this field get matched with the correlation policy and the action specified in the Then field is executed.

While modifying a correlation policy, you cannot change the scope of the policy. If you wish to change the scope, then the correlation policy must be saved as another policy. That is, you cannot modify all the filter expressions in the policy.
If the policy has two filter expressions, you can modify any one of the filter expressions but not both. Similarly if the policy has one filter expression, then you cannot modify it.
An Alarm Threshold Policy is a defined level, an alarm must reach before the system actually reports the alarm. There are currently seven alarm severity levels. They are -
Each alarm severity level has some settings. They are -
The BPUAA alarm severity levels are presented in a tabular format. All the severity levels are treated as a single object.

All the existing alarm threshold policies are listed on the left pane as shown in figure above. Clicking the navigation arrow button on the right-hand-side shows the next alarm threshold policy in the list.

An alarm threshold policy is a collection of individual thresholds. Each alarm severity may be assigned custom threshold values for several criteria. Alarms that fail to meet the required threshold are not raised by BPUAA, however they are still recorded in Event History.

Normally, BPUAA will process an alarm (raise or clear it) as soon as it is received. Alarm Threshold Policies can be used to enforce stricter criteria for alarm processing. Alarms must meet one of these criteria before they are raised or cleared.

Alarm threshold policies may be assigned to individual service end points. This allows an operator to selectively define and apply custom policies precisely where they are needed. This can be used to quiet a node or alarm source (end point) that is babbling, bouncing, or misbehaving in some way.
An alarm threshold policy defines three independent criteria for processing alarm raises. If an alarm meets any one of the criteria it is deemed to have met the threshold policy and is raised.

Once an alarm has been raised by BPUAA it remains standing until cleared by the node. The alarm threshold policy has only one criterion for clearing; the alarm must meet the criterion before it is cleared. This criterion is Clear Soak. If an alarm is cleared by a node, and remains continuously cleared for the specified period it is cleared by BPUAA.
It is important to understand that the start–time of the current period is not fixed; it moves forward in time, so that -
start time = current time minus period length

Using threshold criteria can change how alarms are recorded in Event History. Alarms can be debounced leaving fewer history entries. The duration recorded may be longer than the sum of the raw alarm durations.
This is best explained with the following simple example -

Alarm Suppression is the act of hiding network and service alarms from the operator’s view. Suppressed alarms are hidden from the network and service alarm tables, the service details page, and other views.
The purpose of this is to remove symptomatic alarms to more clearly reveal the “root causes” of network failures.
Suppressed alarms are not actually removed from the system, nor are they cleared. they are merely hidden from view and can be restored at any time using the Show: Suppressed pull–down menu.
The decision to suppress alarms is final. Suppressed alarms do not become unsuppressed if the original reason for the suppression clears.
Alarm suppression is achieved by defining an alarm suppression policy, and assigning the policy to a service.
Symptomatic alarms are those that do not directly indicate or point to the root cause of a network problem.
An alarm suppression policy defines how alarms raised against a high order service can result in the suppression of some or all alarms that are raised against one or more low order services.
To take effect, the suppression policy must be assigned to the high order service. the assignment must be made using the Services editor, in the Alarm Suppression tab.
The policy consists of activation criteria which must be met to activate the policy and a suppression filter which is used to implement the suppression.
Alarm suppression policies are “re–usable”. Once defined, a policy may be assigned to any number of similar services.
When an alarm suppression policy is associated with a service, that service is designated as the high order service. A high order service usually supports one or more low order services.

Low order services are those that depend directly on the designated high order service. the direct dependency must be specified in each of the low order service’s segments list. the segment list is maintained using the Services editor in the Segments tab.

A high order expression is a filter that is used to examine alarms raised against the high order service. the filter specifies the alarms which activate the suppression policy. these expressions are constructed and behave exactly like those used in display or workflow filters. If the filter returns no alarms the policy will not be activated.
A low order expression is a filter that is used to examine alarms raised against all of the low order services. the filter specifies which alarms must be present to activate the suppression policy.

To activate the suppression policy the low order alarm threshold also must be met. this threshold requires that at least the specified percentage of low order services is reporting the alarms specified by the filter.
These expressions are constructed and behave exactly like those used in display or workflow filters.
Low order expressions are optional. If a low order expression is not specified, the policy will rely solely on the high order expressions.
This is the percentage of low order services that must report the alarms specified by the low order expressions before the policy can be activated. It is expressed as a value 0–

The suppression filter selects which alarms will be suppressed. this filter is often identical to the low order expressions but does not have to be. the suppression filter is constructed exactly like display and workflow filters. Unlike those filters, the suppression filter determines which alarms will not be displayed.

The policies are presented in a tabular format. Alarm suppression requires an accurate service containment model. To understand how alarm suppression policies work, the reader should be familiar with End Points, Services and the Service Containment Model.

content.text: Enter the Name of Suppression Policy
The percentage of low order services that must report alarms (as specified by the Low Order Expressions) before the policy is activated.
The suppression filter. this filter specifies which alarms will be suppressed if the policy is activated.

High order expressions specify which alarms must be raised against the high order service in order to activate the policy. The High Order Expressions tab is used to manage the policy’s high order expressions. The tab contains a table of expressions. On this tab expressions can be created, modified, or deleted.
When the table contains multiple expressions (filters), the expressions are added to form a composite filter. At least one alarm must satisfy any and all expressions before the policy is activated.
If the table contains no expressions, any alarms raised against the high order service will be sufficient to activate the policy.

The low order expressions specify which alarms must be raised against the low order services in order to activate the policy. The low order expressions tab is used to manage the policy’s low order expressions. The tab contains a table of expressions that can be created, modified or deleted.
When the table contains multiple expressions (filters), the expressions are AND to form a composite filter. At least one alarm must satisfy any and all expressions before the policy can be activated.
If the table contains no expressions any alarms raised against the low order service may be sufficient to activate the policy as long as the low order alarm threshold is met.

content.text: The Audible Alarm Notification Policies feature is developed with an intention to grab the attention of Network Operators for alarms that need immediate response. This feature is based on policy framework and facilitates creation of multiple policies with relative priorities to manage the audible alarm notification.
The Audible Alarm Notification Policies feature is a licensed feature.
To use this feature perform the following procedures -
As mentioned, the Audible Alarm Notification Policies feature is based on policy framework. You can create multiple policies with relative priorities to manage the audible alarm notification.
An audible sound associated with an alarm is played whenever the alarm is raised. The audible sounds are played for standing alarms that are in the active alarm list.
Audible alarm notification policies are applied on alarms that are visible to the logged in user.

Audible alarm notification is played only if Active Alarms page is open and the Pause button on Active Alarms page is not clicked. If a user pauses auto-refresh of Network Alarms page on a client browser by using the Pause button, the audible alarm notification will get paused as well. On resuming, the alarms will get updated, and will resume audible alarm notification.

If a user has kept multiple Network Alarms pages open in a single session, then each page is considered separately while evaluating alarm policies and multiple audio files might be played at the same time.

Periodically, BPUAA scans all the active alarms and matches against the enabled audible alarm notification policies in the order of their priority. The policy gets matched with the active alarm(s) based on the filter expression defined for the policy while creating it. Once a policy is matched, the notification sound file attached to the policy will be played on the client browser.
The alarm notification behavior with the priorities is explained with examples in Table below.

content.text: Resource Adapter customization is defined as the ability to customize any alarm attribute and/or change the alarm mapping after it has been normalized by a profile or Resource Adapter, before it is passed to the alarm manager. This means, you are allowed to customize alarms to a very specific level (if node x, port y, alarm z then severity = critical). This customization is termed as rule.
This page is only accessible to users with the Network Admin role.

Test Mode is used to test a rule. User can observe how a rule is going to impact the incoming trap/alarm or event without even affecting the actual trap/alarm or event.
This icon is used to change the customization rule priority to move to the top of the list.
Based on the priority, the rules gets executed (if enabled). In above example, the rule with priority 4 will be executed first and priority 1 will be executed last.
forward() is used: when forward is encountered in a rule, the subsequent Rules will be skipped and alarm will be forwarded to FME to persist.
discard() us used: when discard is encountered in a rule, the subsequent Rules will be skipped and the alarm will be discarded.

The discard() function will discard the incoming traps. The alarms for which the discard() function is applied, will not be passed to the uaa-core and uaa-fme container. Once the discard() function is executed, subsequent rules will not be executed for the trap.

The assignment of Application Monitors to Network Elements are managed through application monitor templates.
These application monitoring templates will have certain application monitors assigned to it.

Application monitoring templates can enable BPUAA to dynamically discover monitoring on a set of nodes and apply the monitoring in a configurable “best-effort” manner. The discovery component would define the test that is run to determine if the application monitor should be put in place and the application monitor is the existing monitoring framework.

One of these discovery components is a no-op (No Rules Selected) which results in always on. This allows BPUAA to dynamically determine what monitoring should be put in place and do so automatically. It also allows BPUAA the ability to apply monitoring on a per-interface basis on a server. Application monitoring configuration has the ability to define a set of application monitors for the node; with subsets of application monitors specified for different interfaces or different types of interfaces. For example, if port is X then apply monitors Y.
BPUAA supports two system templates which are available by default on installation of BPUAA. They are -
The system templates do not belong to any domain and can be viewed / used by any domain users.
The system templates cannot be deleted. Global users can edit the system templates, however domain specific users cannot edit the system application monitor templates.

content.text: End Point Templates enable you to mention the configuration options for end points and cable modems. The purpose of end point templates is to reduce redundant information, in cases where groups of end points have same settings. These templates enable the easy management of end point properties on a large scale, and promote uniform configuration across similar end points. When an end point is inventoried, the Resource Adapter specifies a default template, if not, the system default template will be applied to the end point.
The template associated with an end point can be changed using the End Point editor.
The End Point Templates are applicable to the following types of end points -
BPUAA has the following system default and Resource Adapter end point templates.

The System Default End Point Template will be assigned to inventoried end points, when no other template is available. This template should not be modified as it may be replaced during software upgrades. The default template disables Performance functions.
The Network Administrator can create any number of custom end point templates.

The Revert Template option allows you to return the template of end points back to the one either specified by the Resource Adapter, or the default template.

When you select the Revert Template option for a template from the End Point Templates page, for all the end points using the template, the template gets returned to the default template specified by Resource Adapter or system default template.

When you select the Revert Template option for an end point from the end point context menu, the default template specified by Resource Adapter or system default template for that particular end point get assigned to the end point.

BPUAA provides the facility to store a set of values describing the configuration of network elements through Node templates. The purpose of node templates is to reduce redundant information, in cases where groups of nodes have same settings. These templates enable the easy management of node properties on a large scale, and promote uniform configuration across similar nodes. It also helps in operational and administrative purposes to monitor and maintain the network elements and the configuration options and values applied to them.
When a node is discovered, the Resource Adapter specifies a default template for the node, if not, the system default template will be applied to the node.
When a Node Template is attached to a node, a specific set of rules and properties that define the connection and management of the node or group of nodes get associated with the node.

By default, when BPUAA is installed, five different types of node templates called as System Templates and four different types of Resource Adapter templates get created. You can create a Custom node template from the Create option to specify connection and management parameters for a node or group of nodes.

The connection retry count determines how many times BPUAA will retry a keep– alive request before declaring an SNMP node disconnected and raising a communications alarm.This override can be used to accommodate nodes that may become unresponsive for short periods, but are otherwise functioning properly.If this field is true, the node’s connection retry count is used for keep–alive requests instead of the system default value.
The number of times BPUAA will retry a failed keep–alive request before declaring an SNMP node disconnected.
If this field is empty, the system default value is used.

Although SNMP is not a connection–oriented protocol, BPUAA will treat an SNMP node as connected as long as the node will respond to periodic snmp– get requests. This requires that the node is reachable and that the correct community is defined. These requests are known as keep–alive requests.
This override can be used to accommodate nodes that respond correctly, but too slowly to use the default timeout.

The alarm source and node name are used to define and identify alarm end points. For SNMP nodes, the alarm source is composed from one or more varbind values found in the SNMP trap. The varbinds to use are defined by the node’s profile.

An SNMP trap Protocol Data Unit (PDU) has many variable bindings (varbinds) in it.
The pattern of the alarm source name can be specified using these varbind parameters.
If you mention the pattern as $1$2 then, the source name obtained from the varbind Oids/indexes specified in Parameter $1 and $2 will be combined and displayed.
These fields are displayed when the Alarm Source override check box is selected.

When an SNMP trap is processed, BPUAA copies all of the trap’s varbinds into the Additional Information field of the resulting event. This is useful for debugging and to determine the order of the varbinds (That is, to find a varbind index) for use in Alarm Source Patterns and so on.
In many cases, the Additional Information field simply contains too much data to be useful.

The purpose of service templates is that all types of service analysis will be configured automatically when a new service is discovered. All aspects of the analytic functions will be defined in a global fashion and not defined per service. Specifically, the configuration will be defined for the most part in a service template. Services, then, will automatically be assigned a template based on service type thus providing automatic configuration.
With a service template, when a new service is added, all service Analytic get configured for the service automatically.
All the aspects of service Analytics such as -
are defined in a service template. When services such as EVCs, VLANs, and Layer2 adjacency are discovered, then, service templates will automatically be assigned based on service type.

A service can be Available, Unavailable or At risk based on the event condition specified for a service.
Aggregation policy calculation takes place every one minute. Aggregation policy is based on the availability of child services. We have two options -
If you select Any child, then you can specify as the parent service will be At risk, if any of the child is at risk or unavailable.
Service Unavailable, if any child is Unavailable.
If mentioned percentage of child services are Unavailable or At risk, the service will become Unavailable or At risk, as defined in the aggregation policy.
When an Event policy and an aggregation policy both are defined for a service, then the most critical condition takes the priority and gets applied to the service.
For example, a service has both of the following conditions meeting -
Then the service will be Unavailable.

A boolean field (check box) is added which states whether to consider the node’s availability in service’s availability status. If enabled, node’s availability will be considered in service availability calculation and the node availability state will be propagated to the service.

Service quality is a measure of how well the service is performing. It is derived entirely from performance data. All measures of service quality (or Key Quality Indicators) are defined as metrics on the service. There could be any number based on what the service is.
The overall quality is then a summary of the metrics which is simply defined as a grade.

The Performance Metrics tab is used to add metric references to a service template. Performance metrics tab displays all the service metrics and metric of metrics available in the system, that is: metrics with protocol 'service' and 'metric'.
The performance computation frequency is derived from maximum pm collection frequency of selected data sources.
The last poll value of the data sources should be used to calculate EVC PM.
All Service Templates are assigned PMs related to the service's Health, Significance, and Urgency by default.

An application monitor checks if applications are working on or for a device. BPUAA supports two types of application monitors, Script and SNMP MIB. These two application monitors are used to monitor basic availability of network services such as DNS, NTP, SMTP and so on.

Application monitors may be activated on any node to test an application hosted on the node. Using a prompt or password challenge, they check if the application is listening on the specified port, and if it responds to connection attempts. In some cases a simple command or request is made to verify basic operation. If the test fails, an Application Failure Alarm is raised against the node.
A set of application monitors are added to BPUAA by default when the BPUAA Monitor package is installed. They are -
Count of metrics collecting pm of last one hour
Monitor cpu cores, RAM, hosts of remote server
UAA Remote Collector Stats, UAA Sbc status
UAA Core JVM Stats, Prometheus JVM Stats, UAA Application JVM Stats
Monitor go routines, files, cpu utilisation
UAA Hourly PM Consolidation Status, UAA Daily PM Consolidation Status
UAA sbc kafka stats, UAA fme kafka stats, UAA med fme kafka stats, UAA med pme kafka stats, UAA med core kafka stats, UAA Core kafka stats
Monitor message rate and lag of kafka topics

A SNMP MIB monitor is an application monitor which is used to poll snmp devices by giving OID and an expression which can be simple comparison expression which will be applied on the resultant value of poll. Based on the expression evaluation, alarm will be raised/ cleared, if any. If expression evaluation is success, then alarms will be cleared. If there are any standing alarms, otherwise (i.e., expression evaluation failed case) alarm will be raised.

A Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) Management Information Base (MIB) monitor can be used to test a single MIB value against an expected value. This can be used to test for certain conditions on an SNMP node that do not normally result in trap messages. An example of this is testing a node to verify that "traps are enabled", or that the node is configured to send traps to a particular IP address.

The monitor will retrieve the requested MB value with an SNMP get/ Next request and then use an expression to test it. The expression is designed to return true if the value is acceptable. The expression may be a complex Logical Expression or just a simple Comparison Expression.
In addition, the MIB Value Assertion must be specified. The MIB Value Assertion defines which MIB variable to retrieve, and the expression to apply to its value. It is composed of three parts:

When a monitor is activated on a node, the node’s IP address is used to invoke the monitor. This allows a monitor to be defined, used, and reused on all nodes hosting the target application at the specified port. Any variants of these common fields will require the definition of alternate monitors. For example, if some SMTP servers are listening on a non–standard port (say 2525), while other use the standard port (25), an extra monitor must be defined to handle the different port number. If special periods or timeouts are needed for some cases, this also must be handled by defining more monitors.

Follow the given steps to create new Discovery Credential in BPUAA -
Discovery credentials name. The name is not directly editable; it assumes the value of the login (for TL1) or description (for SNMP) fields. Discovery credential names do not have to be unique.
Node’s communication protocol: SNMP or TL1.
The user ID to use when attempting to authenticate with a TL1 agent.
Enter the user name if the protocol is SNMPv3.
Every SNMPv3 entity (agent or manager) will have a user name and password associated with it. See .
It is the unique identifier assigned to the SNMPv3 entity. The SNMPV3 authentication protocols perform authentication using keys generated locally using the Engine ID and password.
The description is used for SNMP credentials only.
Enter the password if the protocol is TL1.
The “SNMP Community string” is like a user ID or password that allows access to data of a router or any other device.

The community string is sent along with all SNMP requests. If the community string is correct, the device responds with the requested information. If the community string is wrong, the device simply discards the request and does not respond.
SNMPv3 uses username/password authentication, along with an encryption key. The default community string is "public".
SNMPv3 provides the following levels of security for communication -
In SNMPv3 protocol terminology, privacy is message encryption.
This security level is enabled for someone with super-user capabilities.

This field is visible only if you select the Security Level as Auth nopriv or Auth priv. Enter an authentication password.
For requests to be authenticated, the manager and the agent must share the authentication password associated with the user name.
This field is visible only if you select the Security Level as Auth priv. BPUAA supports the following types of privacy protocols -
-Advanced Encryption System encrypts and decrypts data in blocks of 128-bit using cryptographic keys of 128, 192, and 256-bits, respectively.

BPUAA is enhanced with the monitoring and management of SLAs. SLA management is a further extension of service assurance. Using this feature operator will be able to identify services that are conforming or violating the service level agreements and also services that are in warning state. This will help users to proactively take necessary actions.
SLA is applied on Services / EVCs. Therefore, to use the SLA feature, you need to install Service Assurance and/or Ethernet Assurance license.
SLAs are only applied to service level performance data. An SLA conformance state/value is obtained from conformance objectives that are derived from the service Performance metrics.
If you select daily, all the data collected in a day will be consolidated and the conformance will be calculated for the day.
A set of Service Level Objectives (SLOs) or conformance objectives and violation expressions for each.
The set of objectives are added to calculate conformance.
A target conformance percentage for the SLA: for example 95% uptime
Utilization > 80 == violation for that SLO Uptime < 50 == violation for that SLO
Following are the fundamental principles used in SLA calculation -
Consider an example to calculate total weight, where -
Now, let us calculate the total weight for this 2 hours period -
Let us assume that the device did not respond for some time and we have only 220 polls at the end of 2 hours, then the weight for this SLA calculation period is 220.
When the SLA conformance is calculated periodically -
The warning and violation alarms raised due to SLA are service alarms. These alarms can be viewed in the Service Alarms page.

header: Points to Consider in SLA Computation

content.text: For a given conformance objective for a service, if SLA Calculation Frequency = 2 hours
content.header: Points to Consider in SLA Computation
Points to Consider in SLA Computation

content.text: If all the metrics have values for a timestamps, the data-point corresponding to that timestamps is considered as a valid data-point.
The weight of these data-points depends on the time period of this data-point.
Assuming, 30 seconds is the minimum PM collection frequency in BPUAA, this is considered as the base weight.
So if the timestamps has a time period of 5 minutes, weight of this data-point is 5*2 = 10 (Total number of 30 seconds in the time period).
Similarly, calculate the total weight of all the data-points in this interval and this is the Total Weight for this interval.
Total weight of data-points crossing violated state (TWV)

Apply the formula SLO defined in the SLA. If the output crosses the VIOLATED limits, add the data-point's weight to the TWV. If the same is done for all the valid data-points, final value is the TWV for this time interval.
Total weight of data-points crossing warning state (TWW)

Apply the formula SLO defined in the SLA. If the output crosses WARNING value, add the data-point's weight to the TWW. If the same is done for all the valid data-points, final value is the TWW for this time interval.

content.text: BPUAA has three standard triggers, namely -
The Standard triggers are system-level objects and cannot be modified or deleted.

During the life cycle of an alarm, the raise and clear triggers will be initiated only once for the alarm, while the modify trigger may fire zero, one, or more times depending on the number of times the alarm being modified.

Apart from these standard triggers, you can create scheduled triggers to define the workflow. Scheduled triggers are global objects. You can modify or delete scheduled triggers, if you have the privilege. Scheduled triggers are used to perform a periodic inspection of the active alarms.

BPUAA provides the facility to store a set of actions (node actions) through Node Action Templates. The purpose of node action templates is to reduce redundant information, in cases where groups of nodes have same settings. These templates enable the easy management of node properties on a large scale. It also helps in operational and administrative purposes to monitor and maintain the network elements and the configuration of actions and values applied to them.
When a Node Action Template is attached to a node, a specific set of rules and properties that define the action to be taken on the node or group of nodes get associated with the node.

By default, when BPUAA is installed, System default and ICMP ping Node Action Template gets created but none of them gets assigned to any node. The template associated with the node can be changed using the Node editor.

This section describes the procedure to create EVC performance metrics.

The polling rate of the provisioned y.1731 OAM test must match the completion rate of the test as provisioned in the network. For example, if the test runs every 30 seconds then BPUAA must poll for the test result every 30 seconds.

The service polling rate as a whole should also match the OAM test. To do this, all associated end points should be set to the same rate: 30 seconds in this case. Otherwise the service will collect data at the default rate of 5 or 7.5 minutes.
The CIR/EIR of the flow points must be set manually to calculate the utilization metrics. The EVC must be manually configured to collect performance data.

Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) is the representation of a mathematical expression in postfix notation that is an operand is followed by an operator . For example, if you are adding two digits 3+5 will be represented as 3,5,+ in RPN.

The base of natural logarithms e
